description.narrative:
The project consists of two parts. One is the (continuation of) the ZAM Chronicle as an important vehicle of liaison between African investigative journalists and their media and ‘Western’ investigative journalists and their media. The second part is a special project of ZAM Chronicle together with the AIPC, which is to conduct a series of collaborative transnational investigations between African and ‘Western’ colleagues.
ZAM is building a multinational platform from where to spread transnational collaborative stories in Africa and in ‘the West’. ZAM is creating transnational collaborative stories. ZAM is initializing debates and further cooperationbetween African and ‘Western’ investigative journalists.
OxfamNovib has undertaken to provide AIPC with a budget to build its capacity and to conduct a series of transnational (and transcontinental, i.e. African-Western) investigations. Details of this proposedbudget have been made available to all AIPC members earlier. The investigations should be around issues of global public interest and include partners on both sides of the globe (Africa-Europe), with publication undertakings from participating media.
Criteria for good proposals will be: 1. (Global) public interest value, newsworthiness and prospective quality 2. A comprehensive and detailed questions list that all members of that TI will work with. 3. Reasonable budget with limited travel (the character of a TI is that colleagues in different places work together, thereby limiting travel needs) 4. A transcontinental team (proponents to select team members on the basis of proposed contributions by the individual candidates). 5. Media undertakings to publish (both in African and Western countries) 6. Format-wise: 1 A4 TI story plan + list of team members, 1 A4 budget.

participating-org.narrative:
To explore and harvest African insights, investigative findings, perceptions, perspectives and creativity in all respects and present these in the Netherlands and on the global stage, thereby influencing and creating more equitability in Dutch and global debates around black and white, rich and poor, North and South.
African narrratives still don’t sufficiently penetrate discourse in the Netherlands and internationally. This is unfortunate because many media stories as well as development ‘agendas’ and ‘solutions’ for problematic situations are based on incomplete information.
ZAM envisages a world where African thinking, investigating and creatinghas impact; a world in which global debates on issues of black-and-white, rich and poor, and north and south are more complete and in-depth. It envisages contributing to this goal in the Netherlands and worldwide.
Zam is working with AIP network in Africa. The AIPC consists of investigative journalists in Kenya, Uganda, Somalia, Nigeria, Ghana, Cameroon, South Sudan, Egypt, Congo Brazzaville, Democratic Republic of Congo, Ivory Coast, Zimbabwe, Botswana and South Africa. This collective contributes ideas, stories, analysis and opinion to ZAM Chronicle. It is expected to grow to include team members from still more African countries. It is ZAM’s partner in the project in this proposal.
